posts.name: mhoye
posts.cooked: In light of Recall storing screenshots every second but by-design refusing to take pictures of DRM‚Äôed content, I‚Äôd like to propose that the Signal desktop client create a one pixel tall by one pixel wide image, secure it via DRM and display it in the client as a defensive measure.

link_counts.title: Protect other users from Microsoft Recall

posts.cooked: Not really any security since attachments are unencrypted on your drive and the database key is also there in plain text.

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked: There‚Äôs only one true way to combat Recall: switch to Linux. It‚Äôs free and made by a charity, like Signal. Most of the apps anybody uses are web-based now anyway, so the only real benefit Windows offers is familiarity.

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
edit: see my own reply
sadly I doubt they‚Äôll use the standards for DRM-encrypted content, they‚Äôre far more likely to just through AI at the problem and call it a day, meaning this approach wouldn‚Äôt work.

You cannot screenshot or screen record DRM protected content. I don‚Äôt see Microsoft circumventing this for Recall. It‚Äôs baked in deep in the drivers.

I believe this would be an excellent default option to have, but it should be possible to disable.

posts.name: Chris
posts.cooked:
Avitus:

so the only real benefit Windows offers is familiarity

Avitus? That is being exaggeratively generous to Linux.

I think people show exaggerated generosity to Windows by still using it. I said goodbye to Windows when they started to require online activation. All I wanted from an operating system was reliability. And they build a system that could stop functioning when you change RAM or a Hard Disk or a Processor. That‚Äôs not how a stable and reliable OS should work.

Looking back now, it has gotten so much worse since I left, that my problem then seems pretty trivial. But I‚Äôm very happy that I made my exit that early and had never regretted it.

But to contribute to the thread and not totally derail it: Windows has much bigger problems than automatic screenshots. And if I was still using windows, I wouldn‚Äôt care to much about Microsoft reading my Signal messages. The biggest Problem would be the huge privacy breach by watching literally everything else on my PC. I really am with @Avitus on this. Should Microsoft dare to go through with their plans, the only reasonable decision for people with even a little sense for what privacy means would be to quit Windows and look for an alternative OS.

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked:
How so? Windows was never objectively good (I remember Windows 95 being perceived as so fragile that adult family members would lose their shit if the computer wasn‚Äôt shut down using the start menu); it was first. Not only was it first, but it was first in a market that didn‚Äôt exist until Windows invented it. The thing that is first is rarely the best at it (look at Ford or the iPhone, for example). And because a first thing is first, there is often no reason to significantly iterate in a way that makes it the best because 99% of the world knows nothing else.

An alternative, modern example is the iPhone. It was the first smartphone of its kind. It was the best smartphone for about 6 years because early Android was a dumpster fire, especially on budget phones. But around 2011 is when things started to shift. Samsung became Android (HTC to a lesser extent) and the iPhone has mostly failed to evolve on the software side since 2011. The most exciting thing they‚Äôve done in 10 years was the ‚ÄúDynamic Island‚Äù which was instantly replicated by an Android app downloadable from the Play Store. But because the iPhone was the first good smartphone, there are a lot of people (mostly American) that perceive it as the only good smartphone.

Linux has its quirks and its learning curve, of course, but the average person can easily pick up Ubuntu just as they would Windows, which is how it‚Äôs designed, but it‚Äôs not the 90s anymore. No average user has to care what a package manager or a distro or a desktop environment is. They just need to know how to follow a tutorial on YouTube.

Getting back to Windows: what does Microsoft offer that Linux can‚Äôt or doesn‚Äôt? You can play games (Steam), you can do word processing/slideshows/spreadsheets (LibreOffice, or just use Google Docs in a browser tab). Microsoft is the high school quarterback that never made it pro and never left their hometown, and talks about nothing but the ‚Äúglory days‚Äù.

posts.name: Tilt
posts.cooked:
Comments as to what operating systems are good and which ones aren‚Äôt are completely moot. Any device you use for secure messaging is your responsibility to secure and if you can‚Äôt secure it don‚Äôt use it‚Ä¶ and if you do, understand the repercussions.

I think Microsoft‚Äôs going to have a huge problem on their hands with streaming services and other DRM controlled media providers and that they will, probably by court order, have to implement something that will allow applications to opt out of being recorded by this new ‚Äúfeature.‚Äù

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked: I stand corrected, it turns out KeePass XC uses this approach and it seems to work.

posts.name: Nospace
posts.cooked: KeePass always had that feature which prevent screenshots, long before recall was a thing. Seems like Recall respects this setting.

But just because Recall does respect it now, that doesn‚Äôt mean it will respect it in the future.

Also, should we mark somehow that this is a Windows only thing? Because I can take screenshots from Keepass, Netflix, etc just fine on openSUSE. I didn‚Äôt even know that screenshots are not supposed to work on DRM content. It‚Äôs perfectly legal to take screenshots from movies or TV show so why should DRM prevent this?
